reviewText:
Soul Reaver 2 starts up where the last game left off. Raziel has plunged through the Chronoplast time portal in his relentless pursuit of Kain and must unearth the mysteries of Nosgoth's ancient races as he travels unabashedly through eras of both the past and the future. Soul Reaver 2 has more in-depth puzzles and improved weapon enhancements, it also introduces a number of elemental mechanics, as well as an increased number of enemies.
As with the original Soul Reaver the bigger focus of this game is the puzzles and these have been much improved and far more challenging. You travel to these various dungeons and you will find far fewer block puzzles and instead a large variety of puzzles that use the differences in landscape between spectral and real realms, reflections, wind, light and elemental reaver attributes. As you progress the game you will receive temporary imbuements to the soul reaver for various elements. These give the reaver various abilities and these are used for the majority of puzzles in the game.
The Story is where the game really shines. The story is so complicated and well written that it spans five games. It is hard to explain the story, you just have to play the games to understand it.
The voice acting is awesome. It is one of the best you will find in any game out there. The music as well is very good, you will find yourself hearing it in your head long after you played this game.
The graphics are great for the time. The graphics now are quite decent, less glitches and more enjoyable lightning sprites. They made Nosgoth's appearance more lively and a better transition effect from Spectral Realm to Material Realm than the first one. Raziel and the other characters were well designed.
The unique play mechanics of Soul Reaver 2, as well as its impressive graphics and excellent story, make it easy to recommend to fans of action or adventure games.

Sounds 9/10
Graphics 8/10
Gameplay 9/10
Atmosphere 10/10

If you liked my review, please feel free to follow me and/or my curator group:
http://steamcommunity.com/id/Ov3RT4K3R/myworkshopfiles/?section=guides
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/orcollective#curation

reviewText:
I'm not reviewing the game itself, but the version currently on Steam and how it plays. That is, depending on your system, terribly.

Lots of people have problems with random freezes during cutscenes, which is a pain since save points are often an hour or so apart and you can't even skip cutscenes you've already seen.

The localized versions of this game, while they exist and are generally considered good quality, are simply not available on Steam. This is English only, and worst of all, this game comes from a time when not having any kind of subtitles was acceptable (way to do accessibiility, by the way).

I don't care how old this game is. If you are republishing it, you have to do basic support. Why are we still paying for it if not this?

Update on this : So it appears the frequent freezes are related to processor affinity in multiple core systems (most modern PCs). There are workarounds, none of which are very convenient for end-users. This could be fixed somewhat easily for everyone if Square Enix had any care. For this reason, and for the non-inclusion of versions other than English, I still don't recommend it.

reviewText: Часть поистине непревзойдённой и уникальной в своём роде серии, где все насущно важные в других играх элементы - геймплей, графика, звук - являются лишь несущей платформой для нарратива. Такого сюжета, как здесь, не было и не будет больше нигде. Эми Хэнниг - автор истории, которую рассказывают игры серии Legacy of Kain - была послана нам с небес под видом человеческой женщины, чей писательский гений тяжело переоценить, и до сих пор является одной из самых успешных женщин-девелоперов за всё время.\n\nКто не играл - пропустил самую необыкновенную, сложную и трагичную историю, которую когда-нибо рассказывали компьютерные игры.

reviewText: Let's get one thing clear: I recommend the GAME, but not in this form. This version of the game is a direct-to-PC port, and comes with the wide variety of accompanying bugs. The Ethereal Plane and water physics are completely broken, for one, rendering the game very nearly unplayable before you even leave the Cathedral you start the game in. If you want to 100% the game, forget about it. I honestly got frustrated trying to explore the first underwater area you come across at the first save point. I recently reloaded the game after several months, and remembered why I hadn't played for so long. That said, if this game is anything like the first, there will be a point that the game becomes completely unpassable due to some puzzle or another not working the way it should. I personally never got that far. I vaguely remember playing the game start to finish when it was first released back on PS2, and I wasn't nearly as clever as I am now, what with being far younger at the time, so I doubt I had the issues I'm seeing now.\n\nTL;DR Get the game for PS2 if you're going to buy it, because console devs have once more dicked the PC port.

reviewText:
Legacy of Kain:Soul Reaver 2 stands as a testment just how a game tops everything off and captailize on it's success in the first game.

However, in terms of gameplay. The controls are really poor even if you bind them to different keys. For example, the directional arrows are your primary movement keys so if you want to use W,A,S,D as your primary movement keys it will cause for some either humerous moments during exploring or combat. But whether or not you will either laugh or get a headache its up to you.

I explore every possible option in the configuration menu to no avail. So if you want to bind your keys to different parts of the keyboard just be wary of which keys you bind it to. As for using a gamepad i will honestly recommend not trying it seeing how there isn't really any options for a gamepad.

Is this PC port terrible? no absolutely not! but by god the controls is the only serious issue in the game. As for everything else it is still the Ps2 version that you all remember.


Again, i would highly recommend a game like this if you want deeper storytelling and brillant dialogue and a mythos to a world so large and labyrinthine. You will come and play again.

This last week, trying to get SR2 running again, I poked around some recent forums to find out about dgVoodoo 2.

If you ever want to be able to play Soul Reaver 1, 2, and Blood Omen without bugs or crashes. Then you want this link. http://dege.freeweb.hu/dgVoodoo2.html

The instructions are easy to fallow, pretty much only requireing you to put files in the game folders, and then using the exe you put in those folders to alter the program, finally alowing the best (at it's time) quality version of a DirectX Emulator, and ridding yourself of most, if not all the bugs that make these games crash. I have finally played all the way through this game, and will be posting the final chapters up on YouTube. Enjoy!

reviewText:
This game is fantastic, but this version isn't. First, it's an incredible pain in the ♥♥♥ to get a controller working, I had to fiddle with JoyToKey for a long time before getting it right. For a game that was originally released on console, this is unacceptable.
Second, and most importantly, the game crashes quite frequently, and considering save points are scarce and the (quite long) cut scenes cannot be skipped, this is *incredibly* frustrating. Also, you have to enable vsync on your graphic card because the screen tearing is monstrous. Audio bugs are also occasionally present, though not to the level of the first game.

I would only recommend the game if you truly cannot get a hold of the PlayStation 2 version at all. PS2 owners, don't bother with double-dipping for the convenience of Steam or the high res or whatnot, and especially not to support the publishers, because they don't deserve your money for this lame cashgrab.

The game itself is quite good, however. Its graphics aged really well and look very good under modern resolutions, the story and voice acting and atmosphere are as compelling as ever, and the level design is spectacular. The camera isn't perfect, it's rather dated, but it helps to bind it on the right analog stick if you can. Combat, similarly to the camera, is both a bit dated yet serviceable enough, and impaling and beheading enemies still feel satisfying.

It's too bad this PC port is so shoddy; no effort whatsoever has been made to make it stable and controller-friendly. This game deserves better than a less-than-mediocre port. I bought this in the LoK bundle during a sale at quite a good price, and I still feel ripped off. After a crash happened which made me lose over 90 minutes of progress (including long, unskippable cut scenes) due the scarcity of save points, I simply gave up on this playthrough (since I beat it more than once on PS2 back in the day).

reviewText:
Oh memories!

I almost forgot about the series until I saw that mod allowing you to get the Reaver in Skyrim heh! I was glad to see that all of them were available on Steam and... I had to give em a try! Last time I played this game was over 10 years ago.

I was first surprised to see how dynamic the whole thing is for such an old game. It's all fast and smooth, from the platform parts to the combat system. Then I had another good surprise when I got stuck with the puzzles or lost as there was not much quest indicators. Games have changed over the years, and not always in a good way.

After spending up to an hour running in circles trying different things to get past an obstacle without success I found myself searching the internet to see if I was not just victim of another bug (happened twice during the game). And NOPE. The game was running well. I just didn't make good use of my brain. I was not used to that anymore!

In most of nowadays games, being stuck on one same thing for such a long time usually means broken game mechanics : You would find solutions such as Quit/reload/restart/patch the game and it MAY work. Eventually.". Here it was not the case. Everything was working as expected.

With that in mind and so few map/quest indicators
date: the only thing left to do is focus on the story and enjoy the ~10 hours this game has to offer. This is a must have.\n\nGet it now!"

reviewText:
Personal rating: Good" = 3/5

PROS:
+ awesome story
+ cool game soundtrack
+ great voice acting
+ enhanced controls and graphics (compared to SR1)
+ two realms - physical and spectral
+ puzzles

CONS:
- weaker boss fights
- simpler gameplay (compared to SR1)
- another open ending hinting to LoK: Defiance
- older graphics
- can have compatibility problems on some PCs

Comment:
Soul Reaver 2 is a sequel to one of my favourite games of all time so of course I had to play it as well. And overall this is a good game that combines combat and puzzles in the various time periods of Nosgoth. This time around the game is less difficult but still keeps it's challenge. The game keeps the mechanic of shifting between physical and spectral realm. Although the return to the physical realm is a bit changed. So if you die in the physical world you shift to the spectral one. There is a rather visible lack of good/epic boss fights in this sequel and while it does make sense story-wise I have to say it takes away from the gameplay a bit. The story and narrative
date: reasons why I love this series
recommended: remain superb. The story telling is enhanced by (slightly) better graphics
hoursPlayed: the writing and voice acting are great as always. I like the soundtrack too. The downsides are that the game is old so graphics and compatibility are really lacking (though it is a lot better than SR1)
voteText: however it runs fine on my Win7 laptop. The ending is reather open again and that can get annoying in this series
helpfulPercent: though it does finally finish in LoK: Defiance. I really like the Soul Reaver series and as such I have to recommend this one as well
votesHelpful: not just because I like it but also because it is a good game worth trying out."
column16: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Firstly i'll say that it is near impossible to enjoy this game if you haven't played the first one (i tried). The story picks up right where the first game ended, so experience the first game before you pick this one up.
Soul Reaver 2 plays the same as the first game but focuses far more on story progression than gameplay. The game is incredibly linear compared to the first game. While the first game had a linear story progression, you did have the option to backtrack and use new found powers to uncover secret items. This game has absolutely no secrets to find. You follow the path and stick to it, beating up a few bad guys along the way using a very stale combat system. During the game you collect different elemental powers for your Reaver, but they really only act as keys to access new areas instead of providing different effects in combat. Combat wasn't such a problem in the first game because you spent more time platforming, but Soul Reaver 2 doesn't have a lot of that, just running from Point A to Point B. It's also much shorter than the previous game. But you see this doesn't matter at all if you're playing it for the story. Soul Reaver 2 isn't about reaching your goal, it's much more about the journey and uncovering one plot twist after another. There's no 'huge' climax at the end of the game, i honestly didn't expect it to end where it did. It acts as more of a story stepping stone between Soul Reaver 1 and Defiance.Just like in the first game, and maybe more so, you will be driving yourself to reach the next cutscene so you can anser that fundamental question, 'why?'.
The voice acting and soundtrack are just as brilliant as the first game. The environment is much less dark and haunting, in fact at the start of the game there's some quite nice scenery.The puzzles get a bit of an upgrade, moving away from block pushing and turning them into something you would find in a Zelda dungeon, but they're not overly hard to solve.
If you're in it for the story then this game won't disappoint, it's the only thing that really makes this games many flaws enjoyable.

reviewText:
The greatness carries over, and where Soul Reaver I would leave absences for expanding upon the same dark narrative... the plot thickens, it twists and turns, and beginning right where the first game ended, we see Raziel follow his course of fate and vengeance, not through Nosgoth, but through time itself. Take again the Soul Reaver, and put those welps and weaklings to pay. Feed on them, grow, as you find the shackles of destiny, and of time itself, clasp about your wrists.

This game is gorey, bloody, just as much so as the first. Raziel must sate his dark hunger.

UPDATE!!!: You should get an xbox controller, or a programmable mouse / controller to play this game. The default controls are shakey on PC, as this was definitely intended for the Playstation. I would most likely extend this comment to all other Legacy of Kain games.

reviewText: A great sequel to a classic game. Great platforming and puzzles, The characters are awesome and well voiced. Follows on from Soul Reaver and answers a few questions which was cool. If you haven't played the first one i would say don't buy the second one, it's story can be hard to understand if you haven't played the first one. Doesn't add much new from Soul Reaver but it's still a great game. If you want to know what happened after Soul Reaver get this. Even if the story isn't your interest its gameplay is still good and worth playing.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
What to say that has not been said already. If this game was a cup, it would be overflowing with epicness.

If you never played it before, you are in for a story you will never forget(most likely you wont understand it either if you havent played previous Legacy of Kain games). Naration is just epic, all voice actors(Kain especially) are very gifted voice actors and will make every cutscene feel amazing. Also, story is well written and leaves little to nothing unexplained but rest assured that after finishing LoK series, all shall be revealed.

Speaking of gameplay, combat is good, fast and dynamic and fairly challenging at some points. Puzzles are entertaining, and a bit challenging every now and then. Only thing that is worse, in my opinion, compared to previous Soul Reaver game is that there are no things to collect, as health upgrades or glyph magic and that the world feels much smaller than the one in the original Soul Reaver

Pros:
-Epic Story narrated by epic voices
-Fast, dynamic combat
-Fun puzzles
-Detailed world and nice visuals

Cons:
-No secret" collectables
-Can crash on PC's with multi core CPU's(avoid by making it run on only 1 core)

9/10"

reviewText:
The 3rd person action adventure in the gothic land of NosgothThe third installment in the LoK franchise. Story begins right where it ended in SR1, in the time streaming device with Kain...
Raziel emerges in another century, and begins his journey to uncover his destiny, again. Now, not on a vengeful quest against his former battle-brothers, but on a quest for knowledge, he will face many obstacles. You will open some ancient mysteries, and gain historical insight about the ancient blue-skinned noble vampire race and it's enemies. You will meet some of the guys that you probably already know (if you played the previous installments), like Moebius, Kain, Vorador... and some new.
Some discoveries during Raziel's inquiry into his own destiny will be quiet suprising.
This game is an amazing experience, from many perspectives. As you can imagine from reading my review, the story is outstanding.
What about the rest of the game?
Well, it's excellent, too
The graphics are old and all, but you can ignore it, the desing and art in game is top-level, has a nice gothic feel too it. Overall looks good even today.
Kurt Harland did a great job making soundtrack for the sequel, it's admirably written. Sound desing imbues the atmosphere with a gothicness and darkness.
The gameplay is similar to the first game, it's a 3rd action adventure with enough of platforming and some nice puzzles. Overall, there's an impovment in most of the areas. Combat mechanics are much more fluid, same goes with probably everything.
Recommend playing this game with a gamepad, it's clearly was ment for consoles, so if you have one, don't bother with keyboard (though, it's still playable, but not as enjoyable in my point of view)
For all fans of the first game this is a must
For those who want to get in to the story of this franchise, this might be your best choice. It's a bit easier than it's predecessor, more fluid and more pleasing to the eye, so yeah, could get you interested easier.
Do strongly recommend this gem!

reviewText:
This review is for young people with Windows 8.1 or other newer systems that may encounter a major freezing error.
This review is not for people who gamed through the mid-to-late 90's and have already played this game before.


If you have already played this game in its heyday, you are likely doing a run-through as you re-do the legacy of kain series and reminisce about the good old days when you had a million hours to play it.  The bottom line for veteran gamers is that you likely know what you're getting into for round 2: a freeze bug coupled with a horrible checkpoint saving system coupled with no gamepad support.  I mean, the first time I played this it was on PC with keyboard/mouse but this time around I'm really noticing how the autoface and combat system would be better served with a gamepad.

I love this series.  I love it.  That's out of the way.  Unfortunately, this is the weakest link in said series.  Blood Omen 2 beats this game in enjoyability.  This game drove me insane.  Imagine spending 35 minutes doing platformer puzzles only for a freeze bug to stop you from saving TEN FEET FROM THE SAVE CHECKPOINT SPOT.  THEN YOU DO THE WHOLE PUZZLE THING ALL OVER AGAIN.  A lot of that.  A lot of jumping over and running past enemies because it just got old and repetitive.  The only driving force was progressing the story, even when it involved walking through the exact same map (oooh but it's in a different time, so it's okay!?) and dealing with the spirit plane and poorly placed planar portals (forgive the alliteration) and running down the same lonnnnnnng hallways because you didn't do something correctly.

The problem is that a veteran gamer doesn't give up.  This game should be rated extremely difficult on the basis of computer glitches and frustration, despite how relatively simple it is as a game itself.  If you manage to finish this whole game whilst suffering through compatability issues, I salute you.  This was not easy for me.  By all means continue the legacy of kain, whether you're familiar or a newcomer, but if you are not looking for reminiscence or gamer cred, I recommend looking up a youtube compilation of all the story cutscenes, and moving straight on to either Blood Omen 2 or preferrably Defiance.

I didn't recommend the first Soul Reaver on Steam because of a sound error that was easily corrected thanks to the save anywhere feature.  Praying that the game didn't freeze before I reached a save point had me ripping my hair out in Soul Reaver 2.  Play if you have spare time or if you just have to, because we've all been there.  We've all played the worst most frustrating games just out of the completist OCD'ness that accompanies our weird generation.

Otherwise, please do not do this to yourself.

reviewText:
While Soul Reaver is widely regarded as a classic hack and slash game. Soul Reaver 2 has more mixed reception from both critics and fans alike.

It's not hard to see why. One of the most replayable elements to the original was it's sidequests. Littered throughout the world were unique power ups that required progressing through the story and getting abilities inorder to unlock. In Soul Reaver 2 there is none of this. You progress through the same overworld continuously, only changing when you switch between time periods. Which really only causes the time of day to shift or snow to appear.

As much as I'd like to recommend Soul Reaver 2. It's essentially a stripped down version of the original. It's only worth getting if you really wanna continue from the cliffhanger SR1 left you with.

reviewText:
I owned all the Legacy of Kain games back in the day on PlayStation and X-Box. Glad to see them make a return here on Steam. Without a doubt the storytelling in the LEgacy of Kain series is probably the best I've ever seen in a game.

- Pros -

-Unsurpassed Storytelling and Voice Acting
-Interesting World Lore
-Difficult but interesting puzzles
-No hand-holding. Figure it out genius
-No lame Twilight vampires

- Cons -

-PC port is terrible. Wonky controls, annoying camera and weak graphics options
-Random crashing
-Long periods between save points
-No hand holding. Help me, I'm lost

All said, it's an amazing story that knocks most story-based games out of the water, even nearly fifteen years after release. (I'm looking at you BioWare)
If you can deal with the wonky and sometimes downright frustrating conrols and the dated graphics, then you should get the Legacy of Kain series. Absolutely.

reviewText:
This game will always have a special place in my heart. It was my favorite game for well over a decade due to its incredible story. The combat was ahead of its time and the puzzles were fun and could be quite challenging. Steam will say that I have only a short amount of time with this game, but that's only because, due to some technical issues with Windows 10, I've been forced to run the game through a different launcher in order to play. If you're running windows 10 or having issues, read on.

Sadly, on Windows 10 and some other newer operating systems, the game can present some major glitches that make it unplayable. These are fixable, but it requires the use of a 3rd party program called DXWND. Some threads I've looked through suggest that the problems can be solved by simply forcing on vsync, but, at least for me, that didn't work, and I tried it through multiple programs and methods. DXWND was the only thing that worked for me. For those interested, these are the settings in DXWND that worked for me:

DirectX 8
Fullscreen only (uncheck Run in window)
Resolution: Monitor Native
Limit the FPS with a delay of 1msec

Everything else I left as default. This worked for me and got the game up and running at 1080p with near perfect 3D Vision support. If you're having issues switching between planes, swimming, or going through enemies when attacking, this will fix it.

reviewText: Exposition simulator! I had this game on the playstation 2, I remember a lot about it. More than anything though, I remember the cutscenes. Interaction between characters who would jawjack each other for so long, you could make a grilled cheese and a pot of chicken noodle from scratch (start it boiling anyway) and still get to see the end of the cutscene. Seriously. The shortest cutscene I can remember is near the end of the game and involves a short interaction with a large demon. It's about the length of a standard cutscene in a regular game. The long as hell cutscenes serve to explain a bit of the worlds backstory a bit and can give you the general idea of what the world is about. Sort of. You still need to play the older legacy of kain games to really understand, but they aren't required to understand this particular games story or enjoy the gameplay.\n\nA word of warning when it comes to the combat btw, you can lock onto an enemy while fighting, it's a bit janky but without it you're basically relegated to swinging wildly and hoping to hit enemies, even if you use a controller. In the late game with those demons I mentioned, that wild swinging crap does not work out. You must lock onto them or you are going to have a hard time. I beat this game several times, and most of the combat I did in ALL my playthroughs consisted of running in circles, jousting" with enemies using the light attack and then running away only to come back and land another

reviewText:
I preferred the first Soul Reaver, that's for sure. And yet, this improved on many things - as I started the game, I was very happy with the upgrades in graphics and animation during cutscenes as well as a definite upgrade in dramatic vampire sass (feat. Raziel vs Kain) Also, I REALLY enjoy this franchise's story, and Soul Reaver 2 does not disappoint in that aspect.

Gameplay/combat system was inferior, however. The first SR was great because the play" was unique - the realm switching lore-motivated no-game-overs style and creative use of environment to defeat enemies was the charm of it.
Soul Reaver 2 dropped all that. Sure
date: it still kept the spectral realm but it didn't serve the same purpose anymore. New enemies introduced that follow you into the spectral realm can actually kill you there now - sending you back to your latest checkpoint. This seemed purposeless? It throws you back into the standard way games handle health and trial & error
recommended: which felt like a stepback. The spectral realm may just as well have been removed completely. The only thing you do in the spectral realm that you can't do in the material realm is distort the environment to be able to scale certain walls.\n\nFighting anybody in Soul Reaver 2 was also incredible tedious
voteText: these vampire hunters are doing their job splendidly when they gang up on you and poke you repeatedly with long halberds and spears
helpfulPercent: stunning you and often negating your dodges. While I don't wish for it to be EASIER
votesHelpful: I just felt like there was no time during combat to catch a break. I was dodging constantly
votesTotal: and still suffered so many blows that it simply wasn't feasible to use the Reaver against enemies. (This may have been a PC port issue? I can't be sure.)\nThe Reaver is a few-hits-kill weapon in SR2
votesFunny: for a price; if you kill an enemy with it
commentsCount: their soul will instantly be devoured by the Reaver itself - leaving you with no way to replenish your health. On top of that
column16: if you use the Reaver too much
column17: it will start feeding directly on your health.\nWithout the Reaver equipped
column18: the souls of your enemies will stick around for you to devour - however
column20: it is difficult to find the time and space to have your meal - if you stop
column22: another enemy will start pummeling you. And sometimes
column23:
that means your meal will escape. (Don't even get me started on the enemies with projectile attacks)
So... Tedious.

(Side note: I'm neutral about the sountrack for SR1 but the spectral realm music for certain areas in SR2 was Really Annoying and was mostly noise. It didn't help that it was usually failure in combat that sent me back to it )
((The portals for materializing back were also waaay more spread out than SR1 so it was a chore to rematerialize))
(((The enemies of the spectral realm were just as tedious as the material ones)))

In conclusion I have a lot of bones to pick with how SR2 was played - however

If you're running windows 10 or having issues, read on.

Sadly, on Windows 10 and some other newer operating systems, the game can present some major glitches that make it unplayable. These are fixable, but it requires the use of a 3rd party program called DXWND. Some threads I've looked through suggest that the problems can be solved by simply forcing on vsync, but, at least for me, that didn't work, and I tried it through multiple programs and methods. DXWND was the only thing that worked for me. For those interested, these are the settings in DXWND that worked for me:

DirectX 8
Fullscreen only (uncheck Run in window)
Resolution: Monitor Native
Limit the FPS with a delay of 1msec

Everything else I left as default. This worked for me and got the game up and running at 1080p with near perfect 3D Vision support. If you're having issues switching between planes, swimming, or going through enemies when attacking, this will fix it.

reviewText: Exposition simulator! I had this game on the playstation 2, I remember a lot about it. More than anything though, I remember the cutscenes. Interaction between characters who would jawjack each other for so long, you could make a grilled cheese and a pot of chicken noodle from scratch (start it boiling anyway) and still get to see the end of the cutscene. Seriously. The shortest cutscene I can remember is near the end of the game and involves a short interaction with a large demon. It's about the length of a standard cutscene in a regular game. The long as hell cutscenes serve to explain a bit of the worlds backstory a bit and can give you the general idea of what the world is about. Sort of. You still need to play the older legacy of kain games to really understand, but they aren't required to understand this particular games story or enjoy the gameplay.\n\nA word of warning when it comes to the combat btw, you can lock onto an enemy while fighting, it's a bit janky but without it you're basically relegated to swinging wildly and hoping to hit enemies, even if you use a controller. In the late game with those demons I mentioned, that wild swinging crap does not work out. You must lock onto them or you are going to have a hard time. I beat this game several times, and most of the combat I did in ALL my playthroughs consisted of running in circles, jousting" with enemies using the light attack and then running away only to come back and land another

I have to say that this game has got the most interesting story-line I've ever seen in a game. The voice acting is the best and it can not be compaired with any other!\n\n

reviewText:
This game will always have a special place in my heart. It was my favorite game for well over a decade due to its incredible story. The combat was ahead of its time and the puzzles were fun and could be quite challenging. Steam will say that I have only a short amount of time with this game, but that's only because, due to some technical issues with Windows 10, I've been forced to run the game through a different launcher in order to play. If you're running windows 10 or having issues, read on.

Sadly, on Windows 10 and some other newer operating systems, the game can present some major glitches that make it unplayable. These are fixable, but it requires the use of a 3rd party program called DXWND. Some threads I've looked through suggest that the problems can be solved by simply forcing on vsync, but, at least for me, that didn't work, and I tried it through multiple programs and methods. DXWND was the only thing that worked for me. For those interested, these are the settings in DXWND that worked for me:

DirectX 8
Fullscreen only (uncheck Run in window)
Resolution: Monitor Native
Limit the FPS with a delay of 1msec

Everything else I left as default. This worked for me and got the game up and running at 1080p with near perfect 3D Vision support. If you're having issues switching between planes, swimming, or going through enemies when attacking, this will fix it.

reviewText: My first impression of Soul Reaver 2 was: This is a cool menu. That's where the good things end.\nAs soon as I hit Start Game"
date: a calamity of bad things started happening. The opening cutscene didn't work
recommended: black screen with sped up audio. The combat is all over the place and then one of the key mechanics
voteText: didn't work either. When I shifted to the spectral realm
helpfulPercent: I was unable to move and the environment didn't change. Because of this
votesHelpful: I was unable to leave the starting area.\nI feel it's only fair to judge it on the basis of being an old game
votesTotal: but also for being an old game that is still being sold.\n\nI cannot recommend it to anyone
commentsCount: because I heard so much great stuff about the Soul Reaver series before experiencing this train wreck. Blood Omen and the original Soul Reaver were great
column16: but this is just downright broken."

reviewText:
Another trip down Nostalgia lane, but unlike the first Soul Reaver, this one hasn't aged as well.

PROS:
+This is the best version of Soul Reaver 2. Besides widescreen problems, the game runs fine at 60 frames a second.
+The story continues and, like the first game in the series, it is masterfully written.
+The puzzles are pretty good.
+You can use the wraith blade whenever you please, which is very, very good--see below.

CONS:
+/- The game repeats itself a little too much. You run through the same areas at least three times. It reminds me of the hub-style gameplay of the first game, but it's done much worse. But it pales in comparison to the other issues.

CONS:
-This is the worse game in the series when it comes to the combat. It a phrase: It's broken. You have a heavy attack and can block now, nice; but the heavy attack is too slow to hit and the enemies' block does not reduce their health, nor does it ever break. You almost HAVE to use the reaver to kill enemies. The AI is horrible, too, since it will keep striking you without pause, not even letting a single hit in. It gets annoying when the enemies can both block everything you have and instantly 7hit combo you to death.
-There are too many enemies. This game obviously has enemy placement that feels copy-paste, almost to the point that I wanted to stop playing.

All in all, this is the worst game of the series, lagging behind Soul Reaver one, and bounds worse than much better Blood Omen 2. I'd only recommend this game if you want to see how the story plays out, but even then, you can easily read a synpopsis on this one (or just the script) and be fine.
